resources.string: Please enter your name so that we know how to contact you.
You need to calculate the gestational age and estimated due date for the application to work correctly.
Enter the first day of your last period.
If you know the Estimated Due Date, you may enter it below:

Congratulations on reaching this milestone! You might be experiencing common symptoms like implantation bleeding (light spotting), fatigue, breast tenderness, and the onset of nausea and vomiting (morning sickness).

At the start of this week, you ovulate. Your egg is fertilized 12 to 24 hours later if a sperm penetrates it. Over the next several days, the fertilized egg will start dividing into multiple cells as it travels down the fallopian tube, enters your uterus, and starts to burrow into the uterine lining. 

 Here's what happens during the 2nd week: 

 Ovulation:
 		• Egg development: An egg starts maturing in one of your 
			 ovaries, inside a fluid-filled sac called a follicle. 
		• Hormonal changes: Levels of estrogen and 
			 follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) increase, stimulating the 
			 egg's growth. 
		• Ovulation event: Around day 14 (can vary depending on your 
			 cycle), the mature egg ruptures from the follicle and is 
			 released into the fallopian tube, ready for fertilization.


Possible symptoms you might experience:
 		• Mittelschmerz: A mild pain or twinge in your lower abdomen 
			 on one side, indicating ovulation. 
		• Cervical mucus changes: Mucus becomes thinner and 
			 clearer, more receptive to sperm.


Remember: 
		• Consult with a healthcare professional if you have any 
			 questions or concerns about your menstrual cycle or 
			 conception. 
		• Accurate pregnancy dating starts from the first day of your 
			 last menstrual period, not week 2.

Now nestled in the nutrient-rich lining of your uterus is a microscopic ball of hundreds of rapidly multiplying cells that will develop into your baby. This ball of cells, called a blastocyst, has begun to produce the pregnancy hormone hCG, which tells your ovaries to stop releasing eggs

Here's what happens during the 3rd week: 
 
		• Implantation: This is the star of the show! By week 3, the 
			 fertilized egg, now called a blastocyst, has traveled down 
			 your fallopian tube and burrows itself into the lining of your 
			 uterus. This process usually takes about 6-10 days after 
			 ovulation

		• Early cell differentiation: The blastocyst starts to 
			 differentiate into two groups of cells: the inner cell mass 
			 (which will eventually become your baby) and the outer layer 
			 (which will form the placenta and other supportive 
			 structures).

		• Placenta formation: The outer layer of the blastocyst begins 
			 to develop into the placenta, a vital organ that will nourish 
			 your baby and remove waste products throughout 
			 pregnancy.


Possible signs and symptoms: 
		• Implantation bleeding: Some women experience light 
			 spotting or bleeding around the time of implantation, which 
			 can be mistaken for a period. This is usually nothing to worry 
			 about, but if you have any concerns, consult your doctor.

		• Breast tenderness: Rising hormone levels can make your 
			 breasts feel swollen and tender.

		• Fatigue: You might feel more tired than usual due to 
			 hormonal changes and the body's increased energy 
			 demands.

		• Food cravings or aversions: Some women experience 
			 changes in their sense of taste and smell, leading to cravings 
			 for certain foods or aversions to others. 
		• No symptoms: It's important to remember that not everyone 
			 experiences pregnancy symptoms in the same way, and 
			 some women might not feel anything at all in the early 
			 weeks.


Health interventions: 
		• Prenatal vitamin: Start taking a prenatal vitamin that 
			 contains folic acid and other essential nutrients to support 
			 your baby's development. 
		•Healthy lifestyle: Focus on eating a balanced diet, getting 
			 regular exercise, and staying hydrated. 
		• Doctor's visit: Schedule a prenatal appointment with your 
			 doctor to discuss your pregnancy and any concerns you 
			 have.


Expectations for your body: 
		• Weight gain: You likely won't experience any significant 
			 weight gain in the third week. 
		• Basal body temperature: If you've been tracking your basal 
			 body temperature, it should remain elevated after ovulation. 
		• Cervical mucus: Your cervical mucus might become thicker 
			 and creamier as your body prepares for implantation.


Remember: 
		• Every pregnancy is unique, and the experiences mentioned 
			 above are just general guidelines. 
		• If you have any concerns or questions, don't hesitate to 
			 talk to your doctor

Your ball of cells is now officially an embryo. You're now about 4 weeks from the beginning of your last period. It's around this time– when your next period would normally be due – that you might be able to get a positive result on a home pregnancy test
 
Your baby is the size of a poppy seed

Here's what happens during the 4th week:
 
		• Rapid cell division: The inner cell mass from the blastocyst 
			 apidly divides and forms three distinct layers: the ectoderm 
			 (forms skin, hair, and nervous system), endoderm (forms 
			 digestive and respiratory systems), and mesoderm (forms 
			 muscles, bones, blood vessels, and other organs). 
		• Primitive streak formation: A line of cells appears within the 
			 inner cell mass, called the primitive streak, which will 
			 eventually develop into the baby's nervous system.

		• Yolk sac development: A small sac outside the embryo, called 
			 the yolk sac, provides early nourishment until the placenta 
			 takes over.

		• Amniotic sac development: A fluid-filled sac forms around 
			 the embryo, creating a protective environment.


Possible signs and symptoms: 
		• Implantation bleeding: Some women may still experience 
			light spotting or bleeding. 
		• Breast tenderness and changes: Breasts may continue to feel 
			 swollen and tender, and nipples may become darker. 
		• Fatigue: Feeling unusually tired is common due to hormonal 
			 changes and increased energy demands. 
		• Nausea and vomiting: Morning sickness (which can occur at 
			 any time of day) may start affecting some women. 
		• Food cravings or aversions: Changes in taste and smell can 
			 lead to specific cravings or aversions. 
		• No symptoms: Remember, not everyone experiences 
			 pregnancy symptoms in the same way, and some might not 
			 feel anything yet.


Health interventions: 
		• Continue prenatal vitamin: Maintain taking your prenatal 
			 vitamin for essential nutrients. 
		• Healthy lifestyle: Prioritize a balanced diet, regular exercise, 
			 and proper hydration. 
		•Schedule prenatal appointment: If you haven't already, book 
			 a prenatal appointment with your doctor for early pregnancy 
			 check-ups and guidance.


Expectations for your body: 
		• Weight gain: Minimal weight gain, if any, is expected at this 
			 stage. 
		• Basal body temperature: Likely remains elevated if you've 
			 been tracking it. 
		• Cervical mucus: May become thicker and stickier as your 
			 body prepares for continued pregnancy.


Remember: 
		• Every pregnancy is unique, and these are general guidelines. 
		• Consult your doctor with any concerns or questions.

Your baby resembles a tadpole more than a human, but is 
 growing fast. The circulatory system is beginning to form, and 
 cells in the tiny "heart" will start to flicker this week.

 Your baby is the size of a sesame seed.


Here's what happens during the 5th week:
 
		• Embryo growth: The embryo grows rapidly, reaching about 
			 the size of a sesame seed. 
		• Neural tube formation: The neural tube forms, which will 
			 eventually become the brain and spinal cord. 
		• Heart development: The tiny heart starts beating, although 
			 it's still a simple tube structure. 
		• Blood vessel development: The first blood vessels form, 
			 connecting the embryo to the developing placenta. 
		• Placenta development: The placenta continues to grow and 
			 take over nourishing the embryo.


Possible signs and symptoms: 
		• Morning sickness: Nausea and vomiting are common, 
			 although not everyone experiences them. 
		• Breast tenderness and changes: Breasts may continue to feel 
			 swollen and tender, and nipples may darken. 
		• Frequent urination: You might need to urinate more often 
			 due to increased blood volume and pressure on the bladder. 
		• Food cravings or aversions: Changes in taste and smell can 
			 lead to specific preferences or dislikes. 
		• Bloating: Increased progesterone levels can cause bloating. 
		• No symptoms: Not everyone experiences pregnancy 
			 symptoms, and some might not feel anything yet.


Health interventions: 
		• Continue prenatal vitamin: Maintain taking your prenatal 
			 vitamin for essential nutrients. 
		• Schedule prenatal appointment: If you haven't already, book 
			 a prenatal appointment with your doctor for early 
			 pregnancy check-ups and guidance. 
		• Healthy lifestyle: Prioritize a balanced diet, regular exercise, 
			 and proper hydration.


Expectations for your body: 
		• Weight gain: Minimal weight gain, if any, is expected at this 
			 stage. 
		• Basal body temperature: No longer relevant for tracking 
			 pregnancy after ovulation. 
		• Cervical mucus: May become thicker and stickier to support 
			 pregnancy.


Remember: 
		• Every pregnancy is unique, and these are general guidelines. 
		• Consult your doctor with any concerns or questions.

Your baby's nose, mouth and ears are starting to take shape, and their intestines and brain are beginning to develop.

 Your baby is the size of a lentil.

 Here's what happens during the 6th week:
 
		• Rapid growth: The embryo, now called a fetus, nearly 
			doubles in size, reaching about the size of a lentil. 
		• Facial features: Tiny bumps appear where the eyes, nose, 
			and ears will eventually form. 
		• Limb development: Tiny buds form, which will develop into 
			arms and legs. 
		• Internal organ development: The heart continues to beat, 
			and the beginnings of the brain, lungs, and digestive system 
			appear. 
		• Placenta function: The placenta starts transferring nutrients 
			and oxygen to the fetus and removing waste products.


Possible signs and symptoms: 
		• Morning sickness: This is still common, and it can affect 
			women differently. 
		• Frequent urination: This continues due to increased blood 
			volume and pressure on the bladder. 
		• Mood swings: Hormonal changes can cause emotional 
			fluctuations. 
		• Bloating: Increased progesterone levels can still cause 
			bloating. 
		• No symptoms: Not everyone experiences pregnancy 
			symptoms, and some might not feel anything yet.


Health interventions: 
		• Continue prenatal vitamin: Maintain taking your prenatal 
			 vitamin for essential nutrients. 
		• Schedule prenatal appointment: If you haven't already, book 
			 a prenatal appointment with your doctor for early 
			 pregnancy check-ups and guidance. 
		• Healthy lifestyle: Prioritize a balanced diet, regular exercise, 
			(with doctor's approval), and proper hydration.


Expectations for your body: 
		• Weight gain: Minimal weight gain, if any, is expected at this 
			 stage. 
		• Basal body temperature: Not relevant for tracking 
			 pregnancy anymore. 
		• Cervical mucus: May become thicker and stickier to support 
			 pregnancy.


Remember: 
		• Every pregnancy is unique, and these are general guidelines. 
		• Consult your doctor with any concerns or questions.

Your baby has doubled in size since last week, but still has a tail, which will soon disappear. Little hands and feet that look more like paddles are emerging from the developing arms and legs. 

Your baby is the size of a blueberry. 

Here's what happens during the 7th week:
 
		• Fetal growth spurt: The fetus grows rapidly, reaching about 
			 the size of a blueberry. 
		• Facial structure: The facial features become more defined, 
			 with eyes forming eyelids and nostrils appearing. 
		• Limb development: Arm and leg buds become more distinct, 
			 with fingers and toes starting to develop. 
		• Organ development: The brain, lungs, digestive system, and 
			 other organs continue to develop and become more 
			 complex. 
		• Nervous system development: The nervous system matures, 
			 allowing for basic movements and reflexes. 
		• Circulatory system development: The heart beats strong and 
			 pumps blood throughout the developing body.

 Possible signs and symptoms: 
		• Morning sickness: This can continue for some women, though 
			 it might start to improve for others. 
		• Fatigue: Tiredness remains common due to hormonal 
			 changes and increased energy demands. 
		• Breast tenderness and changes: Breasts may continue to feel 
			 swollen and tender, and nipples may become darker and 
			 larger. 
		• Increased appetite: As your body nourishes the growing
			 fetus, 
			 you might feel hungrier more often. 
		• Food cravings or aversions: Changes in taste and smell can 
			 still occur. 
		• Frequent urination: This continues due to increased blood 
			 volume and pressure on the bladder. 
		• Bloating: Progesterone levels can still cause bloating. 
		• Mood swings: Hormonal fluctuations can lead to emotional 
			 ups and downs. 
		• No symptoms: Not everyone experiences pregnancy 
			 symptoms in the same way, and some might not feel 
			 anything yet.

 Health interventions: 
		• Continue prenatal vitamin: It's crucial to keep taking your 
			 prenatal vitamin for essential nutrients. 
		• Schedule prenatal appointments: Attend regular check-ups 
			 with your doctor to monitor your health and the baby's 
			 development. 
		• Healthy lifestyle: Maintain a balanced diet, engage in 
			 moderate exercise (approved by your doctor), and stay 
			 hydrated. 
		• Consider genetic testing: Discuss with your doctor if you 
			 have any concerns or risk factors for genetic conditions and 
			 whether genetic testing is right for you.


Expectations for your body: 
		• Slight weight gain: You might start noticing a subtle increase 
			 in weight as your body nourishes the fetus. 
		• Basal body temperature: No longer relevant for tracking 
			 pregnancy. 
		• Cervical mucus: May remain thick and sticky to support 
			 pregnancy. 
		• Possible visible changes: Your clothes might start to feel a bit 
			 snugger around your abdomen, but a noticeable baby bump 
			 is unlikely at this stage.


Remember: 
		• Every pregnancy is unique, and these are general guidelines. 
		• Consult your doctor with any concerns or questions you have 
			 about your pregnancy health and well-being.

Your baby's basic anatomy is developing (they even have tiny earlobes now), but there's much more to come. Their embryonic tail has disappeared and they weigh just a fraction of an ounce but are about to start gaining weight fast.

 Your baby is the size of a grape.

 Here's what happens during the 9th week:


		• Fetal growth: The fetus grows significantly, reaching about 
			 the size of a grape. 
		• Facial features: Facial features continue to become more 
			 detailed, with eyelids opening and closing, and the 
			 beginnings of teeth forming. 
		• Limb development: Fingers and toes are fully formed, with 
			 tiny nails visible. Muscles and bones develop further, 
			 allowing for more complex movements. 
		• Internal organs: Internal organs continue to mature rapidly, 
			 with the brain showing significant development and the 
			 digestive system becoming more functional. 
		• Genital development: Genitals develop more externally, and 
			 in some cases, the baby's sex may be discernible through 
			 ultrasound.


Possible signs and symptoms: 
		• Morning sickness: For some women, this may start to improve 
			 or lessen in intensity. 
		• Fatigue: While still common, fatigue might decrease as your 
			 body adjusts to hormonal changes. 
		• Increased appetite and food cravings/aversions: Your body 
			 needs more fuel for growth, leading to increased hunger 
			 and potential changes in taste and smell. 
		• Breast tenderness and changes: Breasts may still feel swollen 
			 and tender, but the tenderness typically starts to decrease. 
		• Frequent urination: This continues due to increased blood 
			 volume and pressure on the bladder. 
		• Mood swings: Hormonal fluctuations can still cause 
			 emotional ups and downs, but hopefully less intense than 
			 before. 
		• Visible changes: You might start noticing a slight bump 
			 around your lower abdomen, although it's not yet a true 
			 baby bump. 
		• No symptoms: Remember, not everyone experiences 
			 pregnancy symptoms in the same way, and some might not 
			 feel anything yet.


Health interventions: 
		• Continue prenatal vitamin: Maintaining your prenatal vitamin 
			 intake is crucial for continued development. 
		• Schedule prenatal appointments: Regular check-ups with 
			 your doctor help monitor your health and the baby's 
			 progress. 
		• Healthy lifestyle: Prioritize a balanced diet, engage in 
			 moderate exercise (approved by your doctor), and stay 
			 adequately hydrated. 
		• Consider prenatal screening: Discuss with your doctor 
			 whether prenatal screening tests like ultrasound or genetic 
			 testing are right for you.


Expectations for your body: 
		• Gradual weight gain: You might notice a steady increase in 
			 weight as your body nourishes the growing fetus. 
		• Basal body temperature: No longer relevant for tracking 
			 pregnancy. 
		• Cervical mucus: May remain thick and sticky to support 
			 pregnancy. 
		• Possible visible changes: A slight bump around your lower 
			 abdomen might be noticeable, but a prominent baby bump 
			 is still not typical.

 Remember: 
		• Every pregnancy is unique, and these are general guidelines. 
		• Consult your doctor with any concerns or questions you have 
			 about your pregnancy health and well-being.

Your baby has started moving around, though you won't feel your baby move yet. Nerve cells are branching out, forming primitive neural pathways. Breathing tubes now extend from their throat to their developing lungs.


Your baby is the size of a kidney bean.

 Here's what happens during the 8th week:
 
		• Fetal growth: The fetus grows dramatically, reaching about 
			 the size of a kidney bean. 
		• Facial features: Facial features continue to become more 
			 defined, with eyelids closing completely for a short period 
			 and the nose becoming more prominent. 
		•Limb development: Fingers and toes are fully formed, with 
			 tiny nails starting to appear. 
		• Muscle and bone development: Muscles and bones start to 
			 develop, allowing for basic movements like flexing and 
			 kicking. 
		• Internal organs: Internal organs continue to mature, with the 
			 brain showing significant development and the digestive 
			 system becoming more functional 
		• Genital development: Genitals begin to develop externally, 
			 although it's still too early to determine the baby's sex.


Possible signs and symptoms: 
		• Morning sickness: This might start to improve for some 
			 women, while others might continue to experience it. 
		• Fatigue: Tiredness remains common due to hormonal 
			 changes and increased energy demands. 
		• Increased appetite and food cravings/aversions: Your body 
			 needs more fuel for growth, leading to increased hunger 
			 and potential changes in taste and smell. 
		• Breast tenderness and changes: Breasts may continue to feel 
			 swollen and tender, with nipples becoming darker and 
			 larger. 
		• Frequent urination: This continues due to increased blood 
			 volume and pressure on the bladder. 
		• Mood swings: Hormonal fluctuations can still cause 
			 emotional ups and downs. 
		• Visible changes: You might start noticing subtle changes in 
			 your body shape, but a pronounced baby bump is unlikely 
			 yet. 
		• No symptoms: Remember, not everyone experiences 
			 pregnancy symptoms in the same way, and some might not 
			 feel anything yet.
Health interventions: 
		• Continue prenatal vitamin: Maintaining your prenatal vitamin 
			 intake is crucial for continued development. 
		• Schedule prenatal appointments: Regular check-ups with 
			 your doctor help monitor your health and the baby's 
			 progress. 
		• Healthy lifestyle: Prioritize a balanced diet, engage in 
			 moderate exercise (approved by your doctor), and stay 
			 adequately hydrated. 
		• Consider prenatal screening: Discuss with your doctor 
			 whether prenatal screening tests like ultrasound or genetic 
			 testing are right for you.


Expectations for your body: 
		• Slight weight gain: You might start noticing a subtle increase 
			 in weight as your body nourishes the fetus. 
		• Basal body temperature: No longer relevant for tracking 
			 pregnancy. 
		• Cervical mucus: May remain thick and sticky to support 
			 pregnancy. 
		• Possible visible changes: Clothes might feel a bit snugger, 
			 but a prominent baby bump is still not typical.

 Remember: 
		• Every pregnancy is unique, and these are general guidelines. 
		• Consult your doctor with any concerns or questions you have 
			 about your pregnancy health and well-being.

Your embryo has completed the most critical portion of development. Their skin is still translucent, but their tiny limbs can bend and fine details like nails are starting to form.

 Your baby is the size of a kumquat.

 Here's what happens during the 10th week:
 
		• Fetal growth: The fetus grows significantly, reaching about 
			 the size of a kumquat. 
		• Facial features: Facial features continue to refine, with the 
			 nose becoming more prominent and the lips forming. 
		• Limb development: Fingers and toes are fully formed with 
			 tiny fingernails and toenails. Muscles and bones develop 
			further, allowing for more complex movements like kicking 
			and flexing. 
		• Internal organs: Internal organs continue to mature rapidly, 
			 with the brain showing complex activity and the digestive 
			 system becoming even more functional. 
		• Genital development: Genitals are fully formed, and the 
			 baby's sex is usually determinable through ultrasound if 
			 desired.

 Possible signs and symptoms: 
		• Morning sickness: This tends to improve significantly for most 
			 women by this week, although some may still experience 
			 nausea or vomiting occasionally. 
		• Increased energy: As your body adjusts to hormonal 
			 changes, you may feel more energetic than in previous 
			weeks. 
		• Increased appetite and food cravings/aversions: Your body 
			 still needs more fuel, but cravings may become less intense 
			 or even disappear. 
		• Breast tenderness and changes: Breasts may still feel slightly 
			 tender, but the discomfort should be significantly reduced. 
		• Frequent urination: This continues due to increased blood 
			 volume and pressure on the bladder, but might become less 
			 frequent than before. 
		• Mood swings: Emotional fluctuations can still occur, but 
			 hopefully less intense and frequent than earlier weeks. 
		• Visible changes: You might start noticing a more defined 
			 bump around your lower abdomen, marking the beginning 
			 of your visible baby bump. 
		• No symptoms: Remember, not everyone experiences 
			 pregnancy symptoms in the same way, and some might not 
			 feel anything noticeable.


Health interventions: 
		• Continue prenatal vitamin: Maintaining your prenatal vitamin 
			 intake is crucial for continued development. 
		• Schedule prenatal appointments: Regular check-ups with 
			 your doctor help monitor your health and the baby's 
			 progress. 
		• Healthy lifestyle: Prioritize a balanced diet, engage in 
			 moderate exercise (approved by your doctor), and stay 
			 adequately hydrated. 
		• Consider prenatal screening: Discuss with your doctor 
			 whether prenatal screening tests like ultrasound or genetic 
			 testing are right for you.


Expectations for your body: 
		• Steady weight gain: You might notice a steady increase in 
			 weight as your body nourishes the growing fetus. 
		• Basal body temperature: No longer relevant for tracking 
			 pregnancy. 
		• Cervical mucus: May remain thick and sticky to support 
			 pregnancy, but becoming less so gradually. 
		• Visible changes: A more defined bump around your lower 
			 abdomen is likely, marking the start of your visible baby bump.

 Remember: 
		• Every pregnancy is unique, and these are general guidelines. 
		• Consult your doctor with any concerns or questions you have 
			 about your pregnancy health and well-being.

Your baby is almost fully formed. They're kicking, stretching, and even hiccupping as their diaphragm develops, although you can't feel any activity yet.

 Your baby is the size of a fig.

 Here's what happens during the 11th week: 
		• Fetal growth: The fetus grows significantly, reaching about 
			 the size of a fig. 
		• Facial features: Facial features continue to refine, with 
			 distinct human characteristics like eyelids, lips, and a tiny 
			 nose becoming more prominent. 
		• Limb development: Fingers and toes are fully formed with 
			 tiny fingernails and toenails, and the baby might start 
			 flexing and stretching limbs. 
		• Internal organs: Internal organs continue to mature rapidly, 
			 with the brain showing complex activity, the digestive 
			 system becoming more functional, and the kidneys starting 
			 to produce urine. 
		• Skeletal development: Bones become harder and more 
			 developed, allowing for more coordinated movements. 
		• Genital development: Genitals are fully formed, and the 
			 baby's sex is usually determinable through ultrasound if 
			 desired.


Possible signs and symptoms: 
		• Morning sickness: This should significantly improve for most 
			 women, although occasional nausea or vomiting might still 
			 occur. 
		• Increased energy: You might feel more energetic than in 
			 previous weeks as your body adjusts to hormonal changes. 
			Increased appetite and food cravings/aversions: Your body 
			 still needs more fuel, but cravings may become less intense 
			 or even disappear. 
		•Breast tenderness and changes: Breasts may still feel slightly 
			 tender, but the discomfort should be significantly reduced. 
		• Frequent urination: This continues due to increased blood 
			 volume and pressure on the bladder, but might become less 
			 frequent than before. 
		• Mood swings: Emotional fluctuations can still occur, but 
			 hopefully less intense and frequent than earlier weeks. 
		• Visible changes: Your baby bump becomes more noticeable 
			 and defined, and some women might start experiencing skin 
			 changes like a pregnancy glow. 
		• No symptoms: Remember, not everyone experiences 
			 pregnancy symptoms in the same way, and some might not 
			feel anything noticeable.
 

Health interventions: 
		• Continue prenatal vitamin: Maintaining your prenatal vitamin 
			 intake is crucial for continued development. 
		• Schedule prenatal appointments: Regular check-ups with 
			 your doctor help monitor your health and the baby's 
			 progress. 
		• Healthy lifestyle: Prioritize a balanced diet, engage in 
			 moderate exercise (approved by your doctor), and stay 
			 adequately hydrated. 
		• Consider prenatal screening: Discuss with your doctor 
			 whether prenatal screening tests like ultrasound or genetic 
			 testing are right for you.


Expectations for your body: 
		• Steady weight gain: You might notice a steady increase in 
			 weight as your body nourishes the growing fetus. 
		• Basal body temperature: No longer relevant for tracking 
			 pregnancy. 
		• Cervical mucus: May remain thick and sticky to support 
			 pregnancy, but becoming less so gradually. 
		• Visible changes: A more defined bump around your lower 
			 abdomen is likely, marking the start of your visible baby 
			 bump.

 Remember: 
		• Every pregnancy is unique, and these are general guidelines. 
		• Consult your doctor with any concerns or questions you have 
			 about your pregnancy health and well-being.

This week your baby's reflexes kick in: Their fingers will soon begin to open and close, toes will curl, and their mouth will make sucking movements.

 Your baby is the size of a lime.

 Here's what happens during the 12th week:
 
		• Entering the second trimester: This week marks the exciting 
			 transition into the second trimester, which is often referred 
			 to as the "honeymoon phase" due to decreased nausea and 
			 increased energy levels for many women. 
		• Fetal growth: The fetus grows significantly, reaching about 
			 the size of a lime. 
		• Facial features: Facial features continue to develop with 
			 distinct characteristics becoming more recognizable, 
			 including eyebrows, eyelids, and a more defined nose. 
		• Limb development: Fingers and toes are fully formed with 
			 tiny fingernails and toenails, and the baby might start 
			 grasping, sucking their thumb, and making more 
			 coordinated movements. 
		• Internal organs: Internal organs continue to mature rapidly, 
			 with the brain showing complex activity, the digestive 
			 system absorbing nutrients from swallowed amniotic fluid, 
			 and the kidneys functioning more efficiently. 
		• Skeletal development: Bones become stronger and more 
			 developed, allowing for more coordinated movements and 
			 muscle development. 
		• Genital development: Genitals are fully formed, and the 
			 baby's sex is usually determinable through ultrasound if 
			 desired.


Possible signs and symptoms: 
		• Reduced morning sickness: For most women, the dreaded 
			 morning sickness should significantly improve or disappear 
			 altogether by this week. 
		• Increased energy: You might feel more energetic and vibrant 
			 as hormonal changes stabilize and nausea subsides. 
		• Increased appetite: Your body needs more fuel for the 
			 growing baby, so you might feel hungrier more often. 
		• Food cravings/aversions: While still possible, these 
			 tendencies 
			 often become less intense or disappear entirely. 
		• Reduced breast tenderness: The discomfort in your breasts 
			 should be significantly reduced by now. 
		• Frequent urination: You might still need to urinate more often 
			 due to increased blood volume and pressure on the bladder, 
			 but less frequently than earlier weeks. 
		• Mood swings: Emotional fluctuations might still occur, but 
			 hopefully less intense and frequent than in the first 
			 trimester. 
		•Visible changes: Your baby bump becomes more noticeable 
			 and defined, and some women might start experiencing skin 
			 changes like a"pregnancy glow" or linea nigra (a dark line 
			 down the abdomen). 
		• No symptoms: Remember, not everyone experiences 
			 pregnancy symptoms in the same way, and some might not 
			 feel anything noticeable.


Health interventions: 
		• Continue prenatal vitamin: Maintaining your prenatal vitamin 
			 intake is crucial for continued development. 
		• Schedule prenatal appointments: Regular check-ups with 
			 your doctor help monitor your health and the baby's 
			 progress. 
		• Healthy lifestyle: Prioritize a balanced diet, engage in 
			 moderate exercise (approved by your doctor), and stay 
			 adequately hydrated. 
		• Consider prenatal screening: Discuss with your doctor 
			 whether prenatal screening tests like ultrasound or genetic 
			 testing are right for you.


Expectations for your body: 
		• Steady weight gain: You might notice a steady increase in 
			 weight as your body nourishes the growing fetus. 
		• Basal body temperature: No longer relevant for tracking 
			 pregnancy. 
		• Cervical mucus: May remain thick and sticky to support 
			 pregnancy, but becoming less so gradually. 
		• Visible changes: A more defined bump around your lower 
			 abdomen is likely, marking the start of your visible baby 
			 bump.

 Remember: 
		• Every pregnancy is unique, and these are general guidelines. 
		• Consult your doctor with any concerns or questions you have 
			 about your pregnancy health and well-being.
